block.p: Weeks
This
On
Week
List
FICTION
Red Lily, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) A woman who works in a nursery falls in love with the boss's son; conclusion of the ''In the Garden'' trilogy.
The Broker, by John Grisham. (Dell, $7.99.) The C.I.A. arranges a presidential pardon for a power broker who may know crucial secrets.
Memoirs of a Geisha, by Arthur Golden. (Vintage, $14.95; $7.99.) A young woman in Kyoto has to reinvent herself after World War II begins.
Going Home, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $7.99.) Three romances from the archives about women reconnecting with their families.
THE KITE RUNNER, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead, $15.95 and $14.) An Afghan-American returns to Kabul to learn how his childhood friend has fared under the Taliban.
State of Fear, by Michael Crichton. (Avon, $7.99.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
Wicked, by Gregory Maguire. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $15.) A little green-skinned girl grows up to become the Wicked Witch of the West.
Manhunt, by Janet Evanovich. (HarperTorch, $7.50.) A slightly altered reprint of the 1989 novel about a woman who moves to Alaska to find a man.
Prep, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House, $13.95.) A scholarship student encounters a world of privilege at an expensive boarding school in Massachusetts.
Blood Memory, by Greg Iles. (Pocket Star, $9.95.) A forensic scientist probes recent killings as well as a decades-old crime -- the murder of her father.
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) A Harvard scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
Life Expectancy, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $7.99.) A pastry chef must struggle all his life against a family of evil madmen.
Whiteout, by Ken Follett. (Signet, $7.99.) In the middle of a Christmas Eve blizzard in Scotland, a canister filled with a deadly virus goes missing.
Vanishing Acts, by Jodi Picoult. (Washington Square, $14.) A woman who undertakes search-and-rescue missions in New Hampshire discovers that she herself has been a missing person for nearly 30 years.
LIGHT ON SNOW, by Anita Shreve. (Back Bay Books/Little, Brown, $14.95.) During a New England winter, a girl and her father find an abandoned baby.
Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: operation barracuda, by David Michaels. (Berkley, $7.99.) Further adventures of special operative Sam Fisher.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
NONFICTION
A Million Little Pieces, by James Frey. (Anchor, $14.95.) A memoir by a man who was an alcoholic for 10 years and a crack addict for 3.
Worth More Dead, by Ann Rule. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) Five true-crime cases, including the long-unsolved killing of a former marine's estranged wife.
THE DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY, by Erik Larson. (Vintage, $14.95.) The tale of a great architect and a serial killer, who were linked by the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.
THE TIPPING POINT, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) A journalist's study of social epidemics, otherwise known as fads.
Cash: The Autobiography, by Johnny Cash with Patrick Carr. (HarperCollins, $15.95; $7.99.) The life of country music's Man in Black, who died in 2003.
The Chronicles of Narnia: the official illustrated movie companion, by Perry Moore. (HarperSanFrancisco, $19.95.) A behind-the-scenes look at the making of the movie.
When Will Jesus Bring the Pork Chops?, by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $13.95.) Another volume of observations from the stand-up comedian.
JARHEAD, by Anthony Swofford. (Scribner/Pocket Books, $15 and $7.99.) A memoir of the 1991 Persian Gulf war by a former Marine sniper.
In Cold Blood, by Truman Capote. (Vintage, $14.) A murder in Kansas in 1959 and its consequences.
HOLIDAYS ON ICE, by David Sedaris. (Back Bay/ Little, Brown, $8.95.) Comic essays about Christmas by the author of ''Naked.''
The Know-It-All, by A. J. Jacobs. (Simon & Schuster, $14.) A humorous attempt to become ''the smartest person in the world'' by reading all 32 volumes of the Encylopaedia Britannica.
GUNS, GERMS, AND STEEL, by Jared Diamond. (Norton, $16.95.) An argument that Western dominance is due to geographical advantages.
READING LOLITA IN TEHRAN, by Azar Nafisi. (Random House, $13.95.) A memoir of a teacher's life in Iran, centered on a women's reading group.
His Excellency: george Washington, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Vintage, $15.) A biography of George Washington, by the author of ''Founding Brothers.''
A Short History of Nearly Everything, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $15.95.) The sciences and what they tell us about the physical world: a guided tour.
Embedded in America, edited by Carol Kolb. (Three Rivers, $18.95.) A collection of humor pieces from The Onion.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
Love Smart, by Phil McGraw. (Free Press, $26.) Dr. Phil gives advice on finding a relationship or fixing the one you already have.
GUINNESS WORLD RECORDS 2006. (Guinness, $27.95.) A profusely illustrated collection of records about subjects as various as sports and technology.
Your Best Life Now, by Joel Osteen. (Warner Faith, $19.99.) A faith-based approach to living with enthusiasm. ()
THE PURPOSE-DRIVEN LIFE, by Rick Warren. (Zondervan, $19.99.) The meaning of life through God. ()
Redneck Dictionary, by Jeff Foxworthy et al. (Villard, $16.95.) The comedian, a native of Georgia, offers a crash course in Southern conversation by redefining everyday words.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
365: No Repeats, by Rachael Ray. (Clarkson Potter, $19.95.) A year's worth of dinner recipes from the Food Network host.
Why Do Men Have Nipples? by Mark Leyner and Billy Goldberg. (Three Rivers, $12.95.) Humorous answers to hundreds of medical questions.
The World Almanac and Book of Facts 2006. (World Almanac, $12.95). The latest edition of a reference work issued annually since 1868.
1,000 PLACES TO SEE BEFORE YOU DIE, by Patricia Schultz. (Workman, $18.95.) A reference book for travelers.
30-MINUTE GET REAL MEALS, by Rachael Ray. (Clarkson Potter, $18.95.) A collection of recipes from the Food Network host.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Dec. 17, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
